title: Tuesday, 29th August, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
PM11:02am

Morning

PM11:03am

It's still August

PM11:03am

In fact it feels more August than it did last week, in terms of news flow

11:03 am
PM11:03am

So the August rule applies

PM11:03am

Generalised Tinhat

PM11:04am

There's the hurricane, of course

11:04 am
PM11:04am

Hit Texas very hard

PM11:05am

What this means in $$$$ terms v difficult to tell, of course

PM11:06am

Sorry about the doubling up of sessions

11:06 am
PM11:06am

Let me sort that

PM11:07am

Ok, ive deleted the other one -- apologies. Not sure what happened there

PM11:07am

Have a pic -- not of some OAP up to their chest in water tho

11:07 am
PM11:07am

Seen enough of those

PM11:08am

https://twitter.com/chigrl/status/902462666140155904

PM11:08am

There you go -- Harvey in historical context in terms of $$$$ damage

11:08 am
PM11:08am

But you know

PM11:08am

I remember the first time i covered a hurricane in terms of insurance damage

BE11:08am

Sure .........

11:08 am
PM11:08am

There were not estimates, cos it was too early to get a proper figure

PM11:09am

But the instruction from the news editor was to get a figure

PM11:09am

So I got a figure

11:09 am
PM11:09am

Clean made it up

PM11:09am

Things a bit more scientific nowaday I guess

PM11:09am

Hope

11:09 am
PM11:09am

Let me get a bit of grey

PM11:10am

Forecasting storm damage is inherently difficult as the economic price tag for seemingly comparable storms varies substantially

PM11:10am

Yep

11:10 am
PM11:10am

This is Seth Carpenter, UBS in NY

PM11:10am

Forming expectations over Hurricane effects Forecasting storm damage is inherently difficult as the economic price tag for seemingly comparable storms varies substantially. The effect depends on the strength of the storm, population and production density, and details such as storm speed. We expect the effects of Harvey to be substantial and lasting; it was a powerful storm when it made landfall, it hit close to densely populated Houston, and the storm led to substantial flooding. Houston is also a key hub in energy production. However, the timing of the storm, coming late in August, may diminish the influence of the storm on official statistical data if not the true economic effect.On net, we expect a modest drag on US growth in September and likely into October. Activity in November and December should be higher as the rebuilding effect should be well underway and most businesses should have reopened.

PM11:10am

Labor marketsThe hurricane will depress employment in the near term. Employment will likely then rise as the rebuilding effort gets underway and as temporarily-shuttered firms reopen. This swing, however, would not show through fully to the official employment statistics. Jobs numbers are collected during the week containing the 12th. The storm arrived too late for August numbers. For September, net employment could rise or fall, as employment is boosted by rebuilding but may still be hampered by closed business. By October, we expect a modest boost to employment. Our assumed timing effects are comparable to those seen following Hurricane Katrina, which hit with similar timing. Initial claims may surge as early as this week (which we could see in next week's release) and then remain elevated for several weeks thereafter. Super-Storm Sandy, in late 2012, boosted initial claims in the NY area by about 130,000, spread over several weeks; however, the estimated payroll effect was considerably smaller at about 35k.

11:10 am
PM11:10am

Industrial activityAs noted, we expect the hurricane to have a sizable effect on the energy sector. The hurricane is already having a large negative effect on production, exports, refining activity, and drilling. Gasoline prices surged following the storm. Oil prices have fallen. Ample global oil supply, including strategic reserves, is available to fill any shortfall in production. We expect a sizable fall in mining production in September

PM11:11am

ConsumptionHouston is the fourth most populous city in the US. The flooding will curtail spending by its residents in the short term, but we expect spending to rebound relatively quickly, as residents begin to replace flood damaged items, as insurance money flows into Houston, and as households make up for lost spending. We expect a modest drag in September spending followed by a modest spending boost throughout Q4. Sales at building material stores should see a substantial boost throughout as households rebuild

PM11:11am

InflationGas prices are up c.8% in the near term (see next page). This increase will feed directly to headline CPI. We do not expect, however, that the demand effects discussed above will have a substantive influence on national inflation. Spot front-end breakevens have benefited and the breakeven curve has flattened. The TIPS market seems appropriately priced to the shift in gasoline futures but front-end breakevens remain under-priced relative to 1y1y forwards. The Strategy team maintains its recommendation of April18-2y CPI swap based inflation forward (see Please don’t say transitory, 18 Aug 2017).

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Hm. That's a lot of reading.

PM11:11am

Yeah, that'll do

BE11:11am

The figure I've seen quoted most often this morning is $8bn, which is taken from Insurance Insider.

11:11 am
BE11:12am

Which is excluding the Federal Government backed National
Flood Insurance Program thing.

BE11:12am

Windstorm losses of circa $3bn

BE11:12am

Flood is the remainder, though clearly that's more likely to rise than fall.

11:12 am
BE11:13am

Gist from the commentators is that it's the least bad outcome that could have been expected.

BE11:13am

UBS, with a mercifully brief update on all that grey above.

BE11:13am

Should these early estimates hold, we see this as the 'least bad' outcome for the (re)insurers given the storm's severity (see yesterday's reports - EU team, US team). Typically, flood is excluded from US homeowners insurance, with losses picked up by the NFIP. That said, commercial property will be hit and we also understand Swiss Re and Munich Re are leaders on the NFIP's $1bn reinsurance programme. Whilst we see still see scope for notable losses (US stocks with exposure sold off by up to 3% yesterday), we believe these should be mostly contained to cat budgets, with no positive impact on pricing expected. Reinsurers remain on risk for the remainder of hurricane season. Amongst individual stocks, in the context of 3Q17 Cat budgets, we see Lancashire, Swiss Re and SCOR as most exposed.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

And Peel Hunt went through the Lloyd's's.

BE11:14am

Based on precedent, we roughly
estimate insured losses between $4bn and $12bn, excluding the
personal homeowners flood claims to accrue to the NFIP. This is
unlikely to be a market turning event but enough to start to eat into
the Cat budgets and expose the vulnerable underlying returns the
Lloyd’s insurers are generating in the current soft market, with risk
adjusted returns between 10%-11%. A further series of smaller to
medium sized events (in what could prove to be an active
hurricane season according to the NOAA) could force carriers
with slim margins into a loss, triggering further cutbacks and
perhaps a stabilisation of the cycle over time. At 1.9x/1.8x TNAV
2017e/18e, the sector continues to trade at a premium to
underlying returns and we remain cautious on Beazley (Reduce)
and Hiscox (Reduce) whilst more positive on Lancashire (Add)

Beazley PLC (BEZ:LSE): Last: 508.00, down 12.5 (-2.40%), High: 517.00, Low: 508.00, Volume: 427.74k
11:15 am
BE11:15am

Ah, etc. You know how to look at prices.

undefined
PM11:15am

But in terms of the broader market fall...

11:15 am
PM11:16am

PM11:16am

Footsie off 90 points currently

PM11:16am

US futures pointing sharply down

11:16 am

PM11:16am

BE11:17am

11:17 am
PM11:17am

I find the best site for NK stuff is https://kcnawatch.co/

BE11:17am

And the storm, and oil having what we have to assume is a temporary spike due to production being taken out at Eagle Ford and so forth.

BE11:18am

Brent-WTI spread's gone to a 24 month high

11:17 am
PM11:18am

Offers wonderful publications like this: www.nknews.org/kcn.../08/00000420-1.pdf

PM11:18am

Yeah, on the oil front, lots of people tracking Harvey

BE11:19am

Plus the euro at an 18 month high of course.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

And the very real phenomenon of people coming back to their desks post a summer holiday and selling everything.

BE11:19am

So, combination of factors. Let's stick with that.

PM11:20am

Thumbs up

11:19 am
undefined
PM11:20am

Corporate news flow just about non-existent

BE11:21am

Yeah, we weren't around for Kite Pharma getting bought by Gilead yesterday .....

11:21 am
BE11:21am

.... which is mildly interesting.

PM11:21am

WSJ story

BE11:22am

........... yes, landing 10 minutes before the official release out of market hours. Terrific stuff.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

But anyway, $11.9bn deal, only a 30% premium.

BE11:23am

But 70% premium to the August 1st price .... so ........... eh ................

BE11:24am

So anyway, this is reasonably good news for the biotechs.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Assuming Kite's Axi-Cel doesn't get rejected by the FDA in late November, and you have to think Gilead is pretty confident that it won't.

BE11:25am

Suntrust highlighted a few names that would be beneficiaries in the updraft.

BE11:25am

Potentially positive for Juno (JUNO, $30.73, HOLD), Cellectis (CLLS, $25.19, BUY), Adaptimmune (ADAP, $5.21, BUY) and Bellicum (BLCM, $8.28, BUY), now validated that big pharma is getting more interested in cellular therapy and impact on oncology. Other biotech names that could be well positioned given late stage or recently approved targets include Array (ARRY, $9.22, BUY), Clovis (CLVS, $73.16, BUY) and TESARO (TSRO, $126.37, BUY).

11:26 am
BE11:27am

But also, it'll knock Gilead out of the speculation stories for a bit.

PM11:27am

Indeed

undefined
11:27 am
BE11:27am

Otherwise in M&A, I guess we need to note Estee.

PM11:28am

It's not for sale.

PM11:29am

The fabulous Fabrizio Freda says

11:29 am
BE11:29am

..... Yep, and we know this because the Sunday Times took a run at the story we've all been trying not to write.

BE11:29am

Here's the link https://www.thetim...-a841-b272e13cae83

BE11:29am

And here's Freda's statement.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

"The FT is not for sale, there is no process been initiated," [John Fallon] said. "I have not encouraged anybody to think about selling the FT. I've not met with any advisers. I've not received any bids. I've not spoken to anybody I have no intention of talking to anybody. I hope that is clear, that is a singular signal, very clear view on the FT."

BE11:30am

Wait, no, sorry! That was the wrong story!

BE11:30am

https://www.thegua...ital-subscriptions

11:29 am
PM11:30am

hahaha

BE11:30am

Not sure why that came up. Ignore that happened.

BE11:30am

Here's Freda.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

There is no truth to these rumors. The Estée Lauder Companies is not for sale, The Lauder Family and our Board place great value in remaining independent. Our Company is strong and we have excellent momentum going forward.

BE11:31am

So anyway, the best we can offer here is a bit of a recap.

BE11:31am

There was a sudden rush of money towards Estee on August 8th.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Immediately after that, we had a lot of people telling us .... well, nothing really.

BE11:31am

Speculation about possible happenings mostly. Nothing specific, or even particularly useful.

BE11:32am

But there was noise. Lots and lots and lots and lots of noise.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Which I guess makes sense.

PM11:32am

The Lauder family still have an iron grip on this business, no?

PM11:03am

Welcome to Markets Live

11:33 am
PM11:33am

https://www.elcomp...?h=768&la=en&w=615

BE11:33am

Which makes it very risky as a speculative punt. There's no chance of shareholders making enough noise to change anything.

PM11:34am

11:34 am
BE11:34am

So what you're left with is punters buying on what probably sounded like reasonably informed speculation, but no confidence on whether the gossip is likely to play out to conclusion.

BE11:34am

That's where we saps come in. The media.

BE11:35am

We're all absolutely desperate for scoops. The fragility of our egos make for a strong temptation to turn any kind of noise into a story, just so we can say "first!"

11:35 am
BE11:35am

So anyway, spin forward three weeks though silly season and the only places the Estee rumour has appeared are the Evening Standard market report and a few of the GIGO rumour aggregation sites.

BE11:35am

Then the Sunday Times steps in to add some specifics to the noise, which in itself is a useful thing to do.

BE11:36am

As in, Goldman Sachs and Evercore appointed to consider options.

11:35 am
BE11:36am

L'Oreal indicative approach of $122.80 a share, Evercore puts a 'fairness opinion' at $124 a share.

BE11:36am

Is any of this true? Maybe.

BE11:36am

Estee's denial doesn't deny the granular specifics -- as in a mulling of alternatives and a sniff of interest from L'Oreal during that process.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

But then, there's no reason whatsoever why Estee would be that specific.

BE11:37am

What we're left with is a lot of "denies" headlines in the market. All this could have been avoided if Estee had just said three weeks ago, "nah" .... but hey ho.

BE11:38am

Want some sellside? It's kinda pointless but have it anyway.

11:38 am
PM11:38am

sure

BE11:39am

We Like EL's Stock Either With or Without Strategic Potential: In the past, our OW recommendation on EL has been driven by its superior fundamentals not being price into valuation, with much higher topline/EPS growth than peers, driven by EL's exposure to the high growth prestige beauty category, its skew to higher growth and higher margin channels (travel retail/e-commerce) within beauty, and more recently, a building presence in the specialty channel. We have assumed no strategic premium given a lack of assumed interest in selling from the Lauder family, who owns nearly ~90% of voting rights, confirmed by EL comments indicating it is not for sale post these articles, even though there are likely plenty of potential suitors for EL given strong growth in the prestige beauty category where Estée is exposed and potential sizeable synergies with EL's inefficient cost structure.

BE11:39am

This is Morgan Stanley.

11:39 am
BE11:40am

Even without strategic interest, we view EL's stock as compelling here, trading in-line with US mega-cap peers from a 2018 EV/EBITDA standpoint, and at only a 17% premium, below its 25% ten-year average, despite much greater growth potential, with a 500 bp favorable topline growth gap in the most recent quarter

BE11:40am

And Jefferies.

BE11:40am

Estee's Portfolio Widely Viewed As Attractive - Independently or As A Take-Out
Option: EL's prestige-only portfolio has become increasingly attractive as the company
has diversified beyond its legacy core, globalized its innovation platform, and balanced
operations across wholesale, new channels, and DTC. On an independent basis, we value
shares at $112 based on what we see as a fair multiple (25x) for sales (+HSD) and EPS growth
(LDD/low-teens). If we assume: a) any deal announced in 2H CY17 would close in 2H CY18;
b) growth is sustained into FY19/20 implying EPS near $5; and c) 25x multiple holds, we
believe the shares could reach the $125 range.

11:40 am
BE11:41am

Merger Benefits Depend On Parent Co. Structure: Conceptually, savings achieved
on an inward basis and externally via sourcing, marketing, and distribution agreements
would be dependent on the intimacy of a buyer's op model to the beauty category. EL is
on a multi-year cost realignment journey, cutting background expenses and moving dollars
closer to consumer conversion stimulating activities. EL's cost structure ($2.5B core G&A;
~22% of FY17 revenues) has been perceived as a pocket of potential savings (indep & takeout related). Managing legacy brands (est. 50%+ of sales) through a competitive indie cycle
while building on foundational level innovation would be key to sustaining superior mid/
upper teens EBITDA margins. The article cites L'Oréal as the lead candidate, and based on
thoughts from our OR-FP coverage colleague Martin Deboo, the company would appear
the most logical from a strategic, costing, and balance sheet flexibility standpoint.

BE11:41am

Additional Considerations in Any Beauty Conglomerate Takeover - Licenses,
Leases: EL maintains several licenses including: Tommy Hilfiger, Donna Karan New York,
DKNY, Michael Kors, Kiton, Ermenegildo Zegna and Tory Burch. Most brand contracts
include very specific change of control language; any sort of takeout valuation would need
to reflect license transfer risk and/or be adjustable based on confirmation. EL also maintains
a robust DTC business, including physical stores, which bear off balance sheet operating
lease obligations (Note: FASB guideline change pending re: moving PV of leases onto BS).
As of June 30, 2017, EL maintained $2.4B in future lease commitments.

BE11:41am

But anyway, nothing will happen for a bit by the looks of things. If ever.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Best push on.

undefined
PM11:42am

WPP -- no sign of a dead cat there

11:42 am
WPP PLC (WPP:LSE): Last: 1,419, down 18 (-1.25%), High: 1,428, Low: 1,411, Volume: 3.04m
BE11:42am

Not really the day for it.

PM11:42am

Couple of the non-execs stepping up -- in a grudging sort of way

11:42 am
PM11:42am

WPP was notified that on 24 August 2017, Mr Tarek Farahat, Non-executive Director of the Company, purchased 220 WPP plc ADRs at an average price of $93.5276 per ADR. Following this purchase, Mr Farahat's holding is now 420 WPP ADRs (equivalent to 2,100 ordinary shares).

PM11:43am

What's that? $20k or so

PM11:43am

And

11:43 am
PM11:43am

WPP was notified that on 25 August 2017, Mr Jacques Aigrain, Non-executive Director of the Company, purchased 4,000 WPP plc ordinary shares at an average price of £14.389425 per share. Following this purchase, Mr Aigrain's holding is now 13,000 WPP ordinary shares.

PM11:44am

That's £60k or so -- so a bit less grudging that Mr Farahat

undefined
11:45 am
BE11:45am

Elsewhere .........

BE11:46am

There's a nice wee pre-results downgrade of Restaurant Group from Peel Hunt.

Restaurant Group PLC (RTN:LSE): Last: 306.70, down 16.2 (-5.02%), High: 319.50, Low: 305.50, Volume: 987.17k
11:46 am
PM11:46am

ouch

BE11:46am

Sold off last session as well. People talking about transition periods

BE11:47am

As in, you cut the prices on your menus but it takes a fair bit of time to get customers back because they've already abandoned you for Burger King.

11:47 am
PM11:47am

Makes sense

BE11:47am

So, like-for-likes are likely to be moving in the wrong direction for quite a while.

BE11:48am

Peel Hunt notes that Restaurant Group is doing all this at a tough old time for the sector.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Restaurants are the weakest sector in leisure, in our view, needing 2.5-3.5% LFL sales to hold profits, against a backdrop of oversupply and, in many cases, overpricing (and therefore lacklustre LFL sales), and limited scope to mitigate site costs and diversify revenue.

BE11:48am

This year, Restaurant Group can offset its £16m-19m of incremental costs through closures (£10m saving), £5m worth of central cost savings (to be recycled into extra marketing) and £4m from openings. Excluding the £3m impact of one fewer week, it therefore needs LFL sales to be flat in 2017E to hold profits, a scenario that is not going to be helped by needing to cut prices.

BE11:49am

LFL sales fell by 1.8% over the first 20 weeks despite being assisted by a 13.2% increase in cinema attendance and a 7.3% increase in airport passenger volumes in January-April. We expect LFL sales to have weakened in May-June due to a c10% cut in Frankie & Benny’s (F&B) pricing, cinema attendance falling by 9.8% and airport passenger volume growth slowing to 3.9% over those two months.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Wasn't really paying attention to the school holiday cinema slate this year. What were the big films?

BE11:50am

It wasn't just that emoji movie, right? Surely?

PM11:50am

Dunno

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Half the estate is next to cinemas, which helps to drive footfall. However, the long-term trend here favours cinemas (which are adding their own food and beverages) rather than their co-located restaurants. Over the last seven years, average cinema ticket prices have risen by 36% (taking an increasing share of consumer spend), with attendance falling by 3%.

BE11:50am

The pubs should be trading well, but they represent just 12% of the estate. With Chiquito and Coast to Coast also cutting prices in H2, profits are likely to fall further over the next 12 months. Where prices fall by 10%, volumes need to rise by a minimum of 12% to offset. Volume recovery takes time, but cost pressures are ongoing and cost mitigation opportunities are finite.

BE11:51am

Let me skip the forecasts, so Peel Hunt still has something to sell clients. Here's the conclusion.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

In our view, management has done a good job with recruitment, changing the menus (although F&B’s menu is still far too big, in our view), and sourcing cost savings. Some commentators claim the market will write 2017E off as a transitional year, but with price cuts weighted to Q2 and Q3 2017, there is a clear risk that 2018E will also be a transitional year, with profits falling again and requiring a cut in the dividend (which is currently only 1.2x covered). On 16x P/E, we would take some profits; we are cutting our target price from 350p to 300p.

undefined
PM11:52am

ITV mentioned on the right -- it is this Prosiebensat warning I guess

11:52 am
PM11:52am

Warned on ad revenue late yesterday

BE11:52am

Yep, exactly.

PM11:52am

Prosiebensat is down 10 per cent

11:52 am
BE11:53am

All European media stocks getting smashed as well.

ITV PLC (ITV:LSE): Last: 156.40, down 4.5 (-2.80%), High: 160.30, Low: 154.80, Volume: 10.68m
BE11:53am

RTA, Mediaset, etc.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Sorry, RTL. That was a weird typo.

BE11:54am

ITV had already soft warned on Q3 trends, of course.

BE11:54am

As in, still getting worse.

11:54 am
BE11:55am

Pro7 going for mid-single digit decline in TV revenues in Q3

BE11:55am

Which is a sharp deterioration. Exane had +3.5%, of which +2.5% was for advertising

BE11:55am

And management says TV distribution has been fine so it's entirely advertising.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Let me get Kepler.

BE11:56am

Given that it is overlapping the end of last year’s EURO 2016
broadcast and the Rio Olympics, both on public TV, and that this year’s
Auto Fair will be held in Frankfurt in September (it is shared biennially with
Paris), this is a major setback. During the Q2 call, management revealed
that July was up in terms of TV NAR, which could imply that September
was down as much as -10%. Management still hopes that growth will
return to Q4, but we cut our TV growth forecast from +2% to 0%.

BE11:56am

There is no indication of where spending was weakest by sector, but in line
with recent comments by agencies, FMCG (suffering from shareholder
activist pressure to slash cost), Auto and Telcos would seem to be the
potential culprits. RTL Group’s results tomorrow will reveal how much of
this is a market impact, but as well as the possible impact from slightly
softer audience share trends in H1, there seems to be some crowding out
effect from some digital properties previously minority-owned but since
then acquired (Parship, Verivox), whose ad spend on ProSiebenSat1
channels is now excluded as inter-company revenues (“including this spend
ProSiebenSat’s FY 2017 ad revenue could be up low single-digit”).

11:57 am
undefined
PM11:57am

You've done well there Bryce, getting us to 11.57

PM11:57am

Very well indeed

11:57 am
BE11:57am

There's still more, remarkably.

BE11:58am

On Royal Mail, it's FTSE rejig time tonight.

Royal Mail PLC (RMG:LSE): Last: 385.59, down 7.61 (-1.94%), High: 392.30, Low: 384.80, Volume: 1.06m
11:58 am
BE11:58am

Royal Mail's right at the cutoff. Had this been a flat market, today's fall would've relegated it.

BE11:58am

It's not a flat market though, and it's beyond me to do the weightings stuff in realtime.

PM11:59am

hehehe

11:59 am
BE11:59am

I did a filler story about the rejig here, in case anyone cares: https://www.ft.com...-bf50-e1c239b45787

BE11:59am

We'll almost certainly be welcoming NMC

NMC Health PLC (NMC:LSE): Last: 2,665, down 5 (-0.19%), High: 2,669, Low: 2,650, Volume: 83.15k
12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

With its Abu Dhabi family of concert party owner-managers and its 40% free float.

BE12:00pm

We'll be losing Provident, of course.

PM12:00pm

That's a cert

12:00 pm
Provident Financial PLC (PFG:LSE): Last: 908.50, down 7.5 (-0.82%), High: 971.50, Low: 867.50, Volume: 2.03m
BE12:01pm

And we might! be getting Berkeley back. But that's one of several possibilities.

Berkeley Group Holdings PLC (BKG:LSE): Last: 3,729, up 31 (+0.84%), High: 3,738, Low: 3,696, Volume: 267.40k
12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

I suggest waiting for tonight to see the cutoffs, because this kind of market isn't friendly for predictions.

undefined
PM12:02pm

Phew

12:02 pm
PM12:02pm

Thanks for all that Bryce

PM12:02pm

We are done for today

PM12:03pm

Back tomorrow at 11am sharp

12:02 pm
PM12:03pm

Bye

BE11:33am

That's one big problem here, yes. 90% voting rights
